description: NPR's Up First is the news you need to start your day. The three biggest stories of the day, with reporting and analysis from NPR News — in 10 minutes. Available weekdays by 6 a.m. ET, with hosts Leila Fadel, Steve Inskeep, Rachel Martin and A Martinez. Also available on Saturdays by 8 a.m. ET, with Scott Simon. On Sundays, hear a longer exploration behind the headlines with Rachel Martin, available by 8 a.m. ET. Subscribe and listen, then support your local NPR station at donate.npr.org.

items.content: Diplomats are scrambling to avoid conflict in Ukraine, but the U.S. says Russia is ready to attack. Disruptive protests in Canada's capital over COVID-19 restrictions led to a state of emergency. Who are these protesters? And the white men who killed Ahmaud Arbery in 2020 were sentenced to life in a Georgia state court last year. On Monday, jury selection begins for a federal hate crimes trial.

items.title: Monday, February 7, 2022

items.content: For generations of Ukranians, tensions between Russia and Ukraine are nothing new. Rachel Martin talks to Oksana Syroyid, former deputy speaker of the Ukrainian parliament, about Russia's long history of meddling in Ukraine, and what she hopes for her homeland's future.

items.title: The Fight For Ukraine

items.content: Deaths from COVID in the U.S. pass 900,000 even as the infection rate drops. How does that compare to the rest of the world, and what impacts aren't shown by that number? It's the first full day of the Beijing Winter Olympics amid intense COVID testing. The security crisis between Russia and Ukraine continues. We'll have the view from one Russian city that has been providing fighters to engage Ukrainian forces for years.

items.title: Saturday, February 5, 2022

items.content: The U.S. says Russia is preparing a false provocation to justify invading Ukraine. What do we learn from a visit to Ukraine's border? Russian leader Vladimir Putin is meeting with China's Xi Jinping in Beijing. He will also attend the opening of the Winter Olympics, which U.S. officials are boycotting. And the ice storm raging through the Midwest hit Tennessee especially hard. Nearly a third of homes and businesses in Memphis lost power.

items.title: Friday, February 4, 2022

items.content: President Biden this morning detailed the death of the head of Islamic State during a U.S. special forces raid in Syria. In this bonus episode of Up First, NPR's Asma Khalid and Greg Myre talk to Steve Inskeep about the military operation and the president's speech.

items.title: Thursday, February 3, 2022

items.content: What's it like to live under constant fear of invasion? Ukrainians join self-defense units, and trade anxious calls about the future. Former Chicago police officer Jason Van Dyke is on his way out of prison. He served just over half of his sentence for killing teenager Laquan McDonald in 2014. Also, ninety-million Americans live in the path of a forecast winter storm. They include Texans who lost power in 2021. Is the state better prepared?
